comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: That looks like a tripod mounted theodolite on the balcony.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Yes, it does. I'll see if I can find a larger version of this image so we can get a bit more detail....DONE!

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
A larger version will also help to show the built up area on the background hill.

I originally thought this was Kosciusko,  but no way  is that the case with those buildings in the background.

Buildings also make it likely there is a local historical society somewhere that has a good idea where this is.

@Wragge on twitter (Dr. Tim Sherratt) also knows a good deal about the history of meteorology in Australia.  We may need to tap him for this one.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Thanks and for those following these comments @wragge on Twitter was a great help and believes this to be a surveying station rather than a weather station. We will contact the Observatory as advised and see what else we find out.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I think that is Sydney town in the right distance - no NSW country town would have so many spires and large houses.  We are looking west-ish (see shadows) from some surveying spot near Bondi.  Maybe something to do with the Bondi sewage outfall? The large size image certainly helps.

I am amused that with all that surveying equipment etc, they could not get the camera level!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Thanks for the info, beachcomberaustralia. I hadn't thought of Bondi. 

Advice from Sydney Observatory suggests it could be a surveying station or a timekeeping station or a combination of both. To quote: "There seems to be a transit telescope in the shed - that is a telescope aligned exactly north-south and used for both timekeeping and surveying."

comment.author: 9660354@N02
comment._content:
Unlikely to be Bondi or Eastern Suburbs as there is no water visible. Looks as if it is relatively high and if you're near the old sewage outfall at North Bondi you should be able to see either the Harbour or the Ocean. Interesting,
Any date?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
hughp_1998, no, unfortunately there was no date for this image either. It's a real mystery this one. A clue as to the date may come from the outfit worn by the man.

The photo is from a series done by the Government Printing Office during the years c.1870-c.1920

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I hate to have to say this, but I told you so! - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_01_2.cfm?itemid=4570662 and towards the bottom of the page a thumbnail image which links to this - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_01_3.cfm?itemid=4570662... Must be early 1880s. Completed in 1889. The chimney shows in this wonderful picture of Bondi before development when the area was all sand hills and low scrub. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2363539264/]

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
beachcomberaustralia, that is fabulous, thanks for your detective work. 
Transit Telescope for the Bondi Ocean Outfall Sewer it is!

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: beachcomberaustralia - you are the best!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
*blushes!*  Thanks guys, it was fun - keep 'em coming please State Records NSW.

You would not believe how much turgid prose about sewage I had to wade through to find that out.   There is a whole old world under our feet which is best kept at a distance, but still fascinating.  Future industrial archaeologists are going to have fun.

I have been trying to find (via Google Earth) any evidence of the stone plinth in the area.  No luck so far.  A sandstone square, about 2 x 2 metres, possibly higher up the hill than the chimney, but probably on a line with Blair Street (the sewer).  If anyone is nearby, go have a snoop, but watch out for golf balls.

comment.author: 9660354@N02
comment._content: Congrats beachcomber. I still wonder where it was set up? Possibly not at the outfall but at a hill somewhere along the route shown on the route sketch looking toward the City. I liked the links being a civil engineer and having grown up in Rose Bay / Bondi. I didn't realise how much of Sydney was being drained to Bondi to give the great brown river that we could see (& smell) off Bondi Beach.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] "beachcomberaustralia - you are the best!"

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I am not 100% sure about this - one of the stink-pipes is at Bellevue Hill, and may be the location of this photo. Google maps Satellite - g.co/maps/22wec This 1902 interactive sewerage map (!) shows the tunnel is a straight line between Paddington and the Bondi outfall - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-nk7153-sd&rgn=0...

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: You're the best! It's never too late to correct the record.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [12 months later ... ] Boo hoo! The NSW Heritage links above have died. This Sydney Water Heritage Item site has a print of this photo as "1885" on their informative site - www.sydneywater.com.au/Sustainability/OurHeritageAssets/_... . Their photo - www.sydneywater.com.au/Sustainability/OurHeritageAssets/_...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: They changed their domain name and website structure last year. There'll be thousands of links that we have left over the last few years that are now broken. Here are the new links for the two you left above when you identified the image [40 months ago!] ... www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/ViewHeritageItemDe... www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/HeritageItemImage....

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thank you for drying my crocodile tears!  The impermanence of the interweb is going to frustrate us evermore ...  Life is but a melancholy flower.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation ...
